title: Tour de France bike tech 2023: 7 tales from the pits
content:
Cyclist
Tour de France bike tech 2023: 7 tales from the pits

The 2023 Tour de France is in full swing and as ever it’s a mouth-watering feast of delights for lovers of bike tech. Cyclist’s Matthew Loveridge and Charlotte Head were at the Grand Départ in Bilbao and we’ll be bringing you an avalanche of coverage over the coming weeks.

Don’t miss our behind-the-scenes gallery from Stage 1 and our celebration of the fans that make the race so special, plus our in-depth look at Mark Cavendish’s very special bike and the ill-fated Cannondale SuperSix of Richard Carapaz.

Related Posts

Who are the favourites for the 2023 men’s Tour de France?

Lads on (Grand) Tour: The 7 British riders at the 2023 Tour de France

Men’s Tour de France 2023: Stage-by-stage preview and everything you need to know

1. Shimano dominates the peloton

While Shimano only directly sponsors six teams in the race (Alpecin-Deceuninck, Bora-Hansgrohe, Groupama-FDJ, Ineos Grenadiers, Soudal-QuickStep, DSM), 12-speed R9200-series Dura-Ace Di2 is by far the most popular groupset, with a total of 18 teams using it.

There’s not even much variation in choice of gearing. While some teams are running third-party cranks (eg FSA, Cannondale, Look) and there are a number of nominally 11-speed R9100 cranksets still in use, the most popular combo is the current R9200 crank in a 54/40 ratio.

Bigger cassettes are in vogue too. We spotted numerous teams running 11-34 at the back, which a decade or so would have been mountain bike territory.

SRAM meanwhile has three teams in the race (Jumbo-Visma, Lidl-Trek, Movistar), all running 12-speed Red eTap AXS drivetrains.

Finally…

2. Campagnolo Super Record Wireless is… chunky

Campagnolo now supplies just one WorldTour outfit, AG2R-Citröen. The team is running a mix of the existing Super Record EPS groupset and the new Super Record Wireless, both 12-speed.

The latter launched in May this year so it’s very new to the peloton. It’s fair to say its aesthetics are somewhat controversial. Adding separate batteries to the derailleurs has made them rather large. Were wires so bad?

3. Mathieu van der Poel has criminally boring taste in paintjobs

Alpecin-Deceuninck rolled out a special edition Canyon Aeroad for star rider Mathieu van der Poel and it’s amazingly dull. It’s just… white.

The Aeroad is a fantastic looking bike and this paintjob just doesn’t do it justice. Need some proof? Check out the stunning purple design the rest of the riders get:

4. The tubeless takeover continues

While tubulars haven’t disappeared entirely, they’re well on the way to being entirely replaced by tubeless tyres, which will suit the wheel sponsors for whom tubulars are a bit of an anachronism.

It’s now the norm to see pros at the top of the sport riding 28mm tubeless rubber. Tubeless setups are easy to spot because the valves need a nut, and many teams apply stickers to their rims to record the amount of sealant added and when it was last topped up.

5. Integration hasn’t totally taken over (but it’s nearly there)

Integration is a double-edged sword. One-piece cockpits with fully internal cabling look fantastic on the showroom floor but they make simple fit adjustments or maintenance tasks such as replacing headset bearings a major undertaking.

At WorldTour level a significant proportion of bikes are essentially fully integrated, but not all them.

Notable holdouts fighting the good fight for easy adjustment include Jayco-AlUla’s Giant Propels and the Specialized Tarmac SL7s of Bora-Hansgrohe, TotalEnergies, and Soudal-QuickStep.

6. Quick-releases are only good for one thing

With the wholesale move to disc brakes, thru-axles have become the norm, replacing traditional quick-release skewers. QRs still have one important job to perform however – holding spare wheels to the racks on the roofs of team cars.

It still feels like a novelty to watch a mechanic smash a thru-axle in with an impact driver.

7. Not all race bikes look the same

People often complain that all bikes look the same now with their aero tube sections and dropped seatstays, but a walk around the pits at the Tour is a welcome reminder that that’s just not true.

If nothing else, lairy paintwork is more popular than ever, and we love it. Here are some more highlights from behind the barriers…

Follow all our coverage on the Tour de France hub.

author: Matthew Loveridge | Website Editor
